channel.title: The Old Drabblecast Feed
channel.description: Strange Stories, By Strange Authors, for Strange Listeners
channel.itunes:summary:
The Drabblecast is a weekly audio fiction magazine that offers “strange stories for strange listeners.”
Stories feature on the Drabblecast are generally narrated by charismatic host, humorist, and musician Norm Sherman. A full production, the Drabblecast features multiple voice actors, music, and foley effects. The podcast has a finely tuned 'voice' that crosses all genres, including horror, science fiction, fantasy and 'other.' Special features include 100-word stories called, “drabbles,” 100 character stories coined “twabbles,” as well as Norm's own Bbardles, songs based on story themes. Original cover art accompanies every episode.
channel.itunes:author: Norm Sherman
channel.itunes:subtitle: Strange Stories by Strange Authors for Strange Listeners
channel.itunes:keywords: strange, stories, fiction, science-fiction, horror, fantasy, speculative, norm, sherman, anthology, comedy, weekly

item.title: Drabblecast feed has moved!
item.dc:creator: normsherman
item.description: Please resubscribe to the new drabblecast.org
item.itunes:summary: The Drabblecast has moved to new servers. Please update your feed by going to www.drabblecast.org and subscribing.
item.itunes:author: Norm Sherman

item.title: Drabblecast 222 – Rules for Living in a Simulation
item.dc:creator: normsherman
item.description:
Now if we, like those characters in recent movies, discovered specific clues in the world around us suggesting that we do in fact live in a simulation, we would of course consider those clues carefully to see what they say …
read more
item.content:encoded:
Now if we, like those characters in recent movies, discovered specific clues in the world around us suggesting that we do in fact live in a simulation, we would of course consider those clues carefully to see what they say about how we should live our lives. — Robin Hanson

Norm begins this episode of the Drabblecast with an introduction to the new and improved Drabblecast.org, and thanks the many contributors who made this possible. The Drabble by John Murphy remembers a simpler time in video games, though a time not free of consequence. The feature by Aubrey Hirsch provides, as described in the title, a didactic set of rules for living in a simulation (a universe constructed especially for us).
item.itunes:keywords: Artist: Mike Dominic,Author: Aubrey Hirsch,Author: John Murphy,computers,existential,futuristic,games
item.itunes:subtitle: Now if we, like those characters in recent movies, discovered specific clues in the world around us suggesting that we do in fact live in a simulation, we would of course consider those clues carefully to see what they say about how we should live our ...

item.title: Drabblecast 221 – Year of the Rabbit
item.dc:creator: normsherman
item.description:
It used to be that the sun would go down and the streetlamps would come on and make pools of this wet, yellow light. No matter where you stood, you could see the lights on somewhere. You could run from …
read more
item.content:encoded: It used to be that the sun would go down and the streetlamps would come on and make pools of this wet, yellow light. No matter where you stood, you could see the lights on somewhere. You could run from streetlamp to streetlamp and you could look down the streets and you’d never drown in the dark…
item.itunes:subtitle: It used to be that the sun would go down and the streetlamps would come on and make pools of this wet, yellow light. No matter where you stood, you could see the lights on somewhere. You could run from streetlamp to streetlamp and you could look down t...
item.itunes:summary: It used to be that the sun would go down and the streetlamps would come on and make pools of this wet, yellow light. No matter where you stood, you could see the lights on somewhere. You could run from streetlamp to streetlamp and you could look down the streets and you'd never drown in the dark...
item.itunes:author: Norm Sherman

item.title: Drabblecast 220 – Trifecta XVIII
item.dc:creator: normsherman
item.description:
Another of the Drabblecast’s vaunted Trifecta series. Three short stories, each with a unique twist. The episode begins with an interview of author J.R. Hamantaschen, Norm runs fingers through his troubled mind, learning of the seeds from which his horrors …
read more
item.content:encoded:
Another of the Drabblecast’s vaunted Trifecta series. Three short stories, each with a unique twist. The episode begins with an interview of author J.R. Hamantaschen, Norm runs fingers through his troubled mind, learning of the seeds from which his horrors spring. The theme of this Trifecta: getting the boot – stories of rejection and alienation. First up, Richard Weems’s Bad Habit, in which a nun and a naked pervert do battle (no, really). Next, author Andrew Gudgel (featured on fellow podcasts such as Escapepod) appears with Tags, as read by Kimi Alexander, a story of teenage dares in a technologically submerged world. Lastly, A Happy Family, by author, novelist Nathaniel Tower, read by Abner Senires, in which a family receives a very unexpected bundle of joy (and puzzlement).

Episode Sponsor: You Shall Never Know Security by J.R. Hamantaschen.
item.itunes:keywords: Artist: Liz Pennies,Author: Andrew Gudgel,Author: Nathaniel Tower,Author: Richard Weems,children,female narrator,futuristic,games,memories,parenting,punishment,religion
item.itunes:subtitle: Another of the Drabblecast's vaunted Trifecta series. Three short stories, each with a unique twist. The episode begins with an interview of author J.R. Hamantaschen, Norm runs fingers through his troubled mind,

item.title: Drabblecast 219 – The Big Splash
item.dc:creator: normsherman
item.description:
I passed the sign that read Warning: Shark Zone. The sun was setting, lighting up the tops of the condos sticking out of the water. They had been swallowed by the swollen ocean, when it spilled over, like everything else: …
read more
item.content:encoded:
I passed the sign that read Warning: Shark Zone. The sun was setting,
lighting up the tops of the condos sticking out of the water. They had been
swallowed by the swollen ocean, when it spilled over, like everything else:
the skyscrapers, the cars, the fast food joints, the schools and
supermarkets and liquor stores…

Episode Sponsor: You Shall Never Know Security by J.R. Hamantaschen
item.itunes:keywords: aliens,aquatic,Artist: Jonathan Wilson,Author: George R. Galuschak,existential,philosophy

item.title: Drabblecast 218 – Orange
item.dc:creator: normsherman
item.description:
I take time-lapse photographs of an orange. The result is always the same. First I remove the previous orange from the spike in front of the black velvet backdrop and replace it with a new orange. I set an incandescent …
read more
item.content:encoded:
I take time-lapse photographs of an orange. The result is always the same.
First I remove the previous orange from the spike in front of the black
velvet backdrop and replace it with a new orange. I set an incandescent
spotlight out of frame as a light source…

Episode Sponsor: You Shall Never Know Security by J.R. Hamantaschen

item.title: Drabblecast 217 – Followed
item.dc:creator: normsherman
item.description:
She came wandering down the sidewalk like any other corpse, her herky-jerky walk unmistakable among the fluid strides of the living. She was six or seven, Southeast Asian, maybe Indian, her ragged clothes caked in dried mud. Pedestrians cut a wide …
read more
item.content:encoded:
She came wandering down the sidewalk like any other corpse, her herky-jerky walk unmistakable among the fluid strides of the living. She was six or seven, Southeast Asian, maybe Indian, her ragged clothes caked in dried mud. Pedestrians cut a wide berth around her without noticing her at all…

On this episode of the Drabblecast, Norm ponders the nature of the undead. He concludes the In Search of the Brain-Eating Nandi Bear serial. Following that is feature story Followed by Will McIntosh, author of Soft Apocalypse and the upcoming Hitchers.
item.itunes:subtitle: She came wandering down the sidewalk like any other corpse, her herky-jerky walk unmistakable among the fluid strides of the living. She was six or seven, Southeast Asian, maybe Indian, her ragged clothes caked in dried mud.

item.title: Drabblecast 216 – The Book of Eternity
item.dc:creator: normsherman
item.description:
His name was Marvin Kasselmeier, though he changed it to Marcus Magnus because he thought it sounded more impressive. He’d been a bright student, solitary and humorless, with no friends, and a single obsession: he wanted to live forever… Is eternal …
read more
item.content:encoded:
His name was Marvin Kasselmeier, though he changed it to Marcus Magnus
because he thought it sounded more impressive. He’d been a bright student,
solitary and humorless, with no friends, and a single obsession: he wanted to live forever…

Is eternal life real worth it? A demonic tale from Mike Resnick explores the question in the final week of Lovecraft months Story features In Search of the Brain-Eating Nandi Bear Part V.
item.itunes:keywords: afterlife,Artist: Jan Dennison,Author: Mike Resnick,Connor Choadsworth,cryptids,damnation,demonology,eternity,Lovecraft Month
item.itunes:subtitle: His name was Marvin Kasselmeier, though he changed it to Marcus Magnus because he thought it sounded more impressive. He’d been a bright student, solitary and humorless, with no friends, and a single obsession: he wanted to live forever... -

item.title: Drabblecast 215 – Dread Unlocks
item.dc:creator: normsherman
item.description:
Okay, no one expects eldritch horror in LA. Not that I know what eldritch horror really is. My old boyfriend (about fifteen boyfriends back) called anything that inspired dread “eldritch horror.” I guess that would describe my entire job, really… …
read more
item.content:encoded:
Okay, no one expects eldritch horror in LA. Not that I know what eldritch horror really is. My old boyfriend (about fifteen boyfriends back) called anything that inspired dread “eldritch horror.” I guess that would describe my entire job, really…

Another story from Lovecraft month – elder horror in LA. Dread Unlocks is on the job!
item.itunes:keywords: Artist: Bo Kaier,Author: Kristine Kathryn Rusch,dread,female narrator,haunted,Lovecraft Month,possession

item.title: Drabblecast 214 – The Wish of the Demon Achtromagk
item.dc:creator: normsherman
item.description:
Achtromagk shuddered, lost in nightmare images: crimson lightning dotting a wasteland, twilight despair and feeble railings, isolation in a mewling throng. It thrashed and twisted but could not escape, could not stop the unwanted vistas in its mind. It was …
read more
item.content:encoded:
Achtromagk shuddered, lost in nightmare images: crimson lightning dotting a wasteland, twilight despair and feeble railings, isolation in a mewling throng. It thrashed and twisted but could not escape, could not stop the unwanted vistas in its mind.

It was silent. And soft. And dark…

Next up in Lovecraft month, a heart-warming tale of an extra-dimensional Lovecraftian horror (an ‘oh so huggable’ one) by Drabblecast favorite Eugie Foster.
item.itunes:keywords: Artist: David Flett,Author: Eugie Foster,children,dimensions,Drabblecast Original

item.title: Drabblecast 213 – The Haunter of the Dark
item.dc:creator: normsherman
item.description: I have seen the dark universe yawning Where the black planets roll without aim— Where they roll in their horror unheeded, Without knowledge or lustre or name… To kick of Lovecraft Month Norm once again reads an H.P. Lovecraft classic.
item.content:encoded:
I have seen the dark universe yawning
Where the black planets roll without aim—
Where they roll in their horror unheeded,
Without knowledge or lustre or name…

To kick of Lovecraft Month Norm once again reads an H.P. Lovecraft classic.
item.itunes:subtitle: I have seen the dark universe yawning Where the black planets roll without aim— Where they roll in their horror unheeded, Without knowledge or lustre or name... - To kick of Lovecraft Month Norm once again reads an H.P. Lovecraft classic.
